titleStmt.title: An exceeding true relation, of a renowned victory obtained against the rebels on the 2. of May. 1642. On the north side of Tredarth. By the discreet councell, and heroicke courage of Captaine Stutfield, and Captaine Bartlet. Who with a very small number of men slew almost sixe thousand rebels. Being the copie of a letter sent to Mr. Dudley Ratcliffe, citizen, jnhabitant at Tower-hill. Whereunto is added, the copie of another letter sent to a gentleman of worth in London, and read in the House of Commons. Jt is ordered, that this be forthwith printed Hen. Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.
titleStmt.author: Benningfield, W.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Ireland -- History -- Rebellion of 1641 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: Dublin, 9. May, 1642, An Exceeding true RELATION, OF A RENOWNED VICTORY Obtained again≈øt the Rebels on the 2. of May. 1642. On the North ≈øide of Tredarth.
By the Di≈øcreet Councell, and Heroicke Courage of Captaine Stutfield, and Captaine Bartlet.
Who with a very ≈ømall number of men ≈ølew almo≈øt ≈øixe thou≈øand Rebels.
Being the Copie of a Letter ≈øent to Mr. Dudley Ratcliffe, Citizen, Jnhabitant at Tower-Hill.
Whereunto is added, the Copie of another Letter ≈øent to a Gentleman of worth in London, and read in the Hou≈øe of COMMONS.
It is Ordered, That this be forthwith Printed

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for John Reyn ‚Ä¢ r. 1642.

div.head: The Copie of a Letter ≈øent from Dublin to Mr. Dudley Ratcliffe, at Tower-hill in LONDON.
div.p: THe la≈øt Letter I ≈øent, dated Aprill the 18. J wrote to you of ≈øorrow and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, but now God bee thanked, our ≈øighs are converted to ≈ømiles, and our ≈øorrowes into rejoycing, for ≈øo it hath plea≈øed Almighty God to ble≈ø≈øe us in our late proceedings again≈øt the Rebels, that we are almo≈øt quite cleare of them in our parts the manner of our delivery, J will relate at large as followeth.

On the 2. day of May, Mack-mahaun with 10000 Rebels came up again≈øt us we being but 4000 foot and 800 hor≈øe thinkin ‚Ä¢ to put us all to death, or flight, to prev ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ which, upon a decayd Ca≈øtle that we h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ we mounted 4. pieces of Ordnance; Like wi≈øe we ravl'd a block-hou≈øe on the South ≈øide of our ≈ømall Campe, with two ≈ømall
Pieces, being all we had, likewi≈øe our men threw up Walls of Turffe and Earth to ≈øhelter them from the Rebels ≈øhot, and to give them≈øelves advantage to offend the Enemy.

Which being done, Captaine Stutfield gave ≈øtrict command that generall ≈øhouts and acclamations would be heard throughout the Army, the Trumpets, Drums, and Fiffes with their ≈øhrill Notes and plea≈øant accents fill'd the Ecchoing Ayre, our Canons ratled, and with ≈øwifre≈øt ≈øpeed unto the Rebels, gave a Churli≈øh welcome, for our ≈øwift Bullets made a large Lane among≈øt them, the Rebels hearing our joyfull acclamations, began to feare ≈øome Trechery, and as our mirth encrea≈øed ≈øo did their feare, which made them afraid to fall upon us, or to draw nigher for feare the ground was undermined.

Wherefore they tooke their ≈øtand, and with their be≈øt ≈øpeed planted theirField pieces again≈øt our block-hou≈øe, ≈øhooting very oft, though but to little purpo≈øe, for ≈øpight of all their Battries we continued our ≈øhouts and acclamations, in the mean time Captain Stutfield ≈øent out ≈øome Scouts in reque≈øt
of Captaine Bartlet, who was gone with 5. hundred men, to fetch in ≈øome provi≈øion.

Likewi≈øe he ≈øet ≈øtrong watches in their view, though not within their ≈øhot, to make them thinke our Forces greater then they were, that day being ≈øpent, the next day being Tue≈øday, he gave Command that all of them that were in health ≈øhould fa≈øt and Pray, which was with willingne≈ø≈øe effected, likewi≈øe that Night Captayne Bart let came in unto us, bringing in provi≈øion, with which we were repleni≈øhed, our joy and ≈øhouts increa≈øing, the Rebels being amazed and having intelligence of our new-come Forces, re≈øolved that night to ≈øteale away, but to prevent that, we marcht out again≈øt them, charging them ≈øiercely, Captayne Stutfield with three Troops of Hor≈øe, troop up unto their Faces and di≈øcharg'd, making ≈øuch breaches in their Main-Battalia, that Mack-Mahaun ≈øwore he was a Divell not a mortall man.

Our Foot likewi≈øe fired ≈øo fa≈øt upon them that they fell to running, not to fighting, for in the ≈øpace of 4. houres there was ≈ølaine almo≈øt ≈øix thou≈øand of the Rebels, we having
lo≈øt not above 2. hundred men, be≈øide ≈øome three≈øcore maimed.

Captayne Bartlet ≈øeeing their Reare begin to ≈ølye, incouraged on his men, and u≈ød his utmo≈øt power to intercept their pa≈ø≈øage, which they ≈øeeing, (like de≈øperate Cowards) drew up their Ordnance, and di≈øcharg'd upon him all at one time, which made a breach among≈øt our men, which ≈øo incen≈øed them to ≈øee their Comerades fall ≈øo fa≈øt before them, ≈øo that they fell on like Divels never cea≈øing till they had ≈øurpizd the Rebels Ordnance, and di≈øcharged them again≈øt their Ma≈øters, among≈øt whome they did a fearefull execution, the Rebels immediately tooke them to their heels, and we retreated to our Quarters, thus was this great Victory obtained by the di≈øcreet Councell and undanted Courage of the≈øe Noble Commanders, of who≈øe future explovts at my, next opportunity, I will acquaint you with. till which time J re≈øt.

closer.signed: Your Friend and Servant, VV, Benningfield.

div.head: Good Newes from Ireland.
div.p: I Have written by the two la≈øt Po≈øts, and having good Newes, I ≈øhall impart it unto you.

The la≈øt Saturday the Lord Moore and Sir Henry Titchburne ≈øallyed out of the Town, and fell upon the Enemies, and rai≈ø'd their Siege, ≈ølew about 350 of their mens, and tooke many of their chiefe Officers, and have relieved them≈øelves bravely, and tooke 150 of their Muskets, and a Field full of Pikes, we having lo≈øt, as ≈øome a≈øtirme no men. Here are three of our Captaines come by Land, ≈øo that this Newes is true.

Upon Munday our Forces went out, 4000 Foot and 500 Hor≈øe, they are already within 5. myles of Tredagb: by the way; Lievtenant Colonell Reade came into our men, and ≈øubmitted, if he had not done it, he could not have ≈øcapt, he is ≈øent hither,
and lodg'd in the Ca≈øtle, I doe believe w ‚Ä¢ ≈øhall now get good ≈øtore of Corne out of the Country, which will keepe the price from ri≈øing. Our men are not expected home this weeke, pray God keepe them ≈øafe.

closer.signed: With my true love, I re≈øt: Your affection friend, R. P.

div.p: It is this day Ordered, That this bee forthwith Printed

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øynge, Cleric. Parl. D. Com.
